newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: CATHOLIC MAVERICKS SUPPORT S.AFRICAN ABORTION BILL.
newsitem.headline: CATHOLIC MAVERICKS SUPPORT S.AFRICAN ABORTION BILL.

text.p: Two Catholic women broke ranks with their church's official line against abortion on Tuesday, urging South Africa's parliament to adopt a proposed law which would allow abortion on demand.
Catholic Mary Armour told a parliamentary hearing her pro-choice stance was not rare, but silenced in the church by the unmarried priests who run it.
"To refuse women access to contraception as well as abortion is inhumane," said Armour, a theology graduate.

"(It) is unacceptable for a group of celibate men in a church in which women are barred from policy-making and the priesthood to both make and interpret moral laws on women's reproductive choices," she added.
South Africa's two-year-old all-race parliament is considering a draft law which would allow abortions up to the 12th week and for a further eight weeks in some circumstances.
The Catholic church opposes abortion for any reason and has called on the South African government to probe the underlying reasons for illegal backstreet abortions in South Africa.
Catholic church representative Noel Pistorius said any surgical or medical ending of pregnancy was an "infringement of an inalienable right to life and consequently gravely immoral".
But Helen Moffat, a Catholic doctor, said she was unable to support a ban on abortion after witnessing the hardships of uneducated black women who suffered worst.

"The grinding poverty and the hunger...where having another child means seeing your existing children go hungry: as a comfortable white middle-class woman, as a Christian, I cannot sit in judgment on these women," she said during the debate.
Moffat also called on Nelson Mandela's government to increase education on birth control particularly among people in poor rural areas.
Christian anti-abortion campaigners clashed with some members of parliament for a second day on Tuesday over the proposed law, which they said ignored majority opinion.
The campaigners also held a protest outside parliament on Tuesday, waving placards and handing anti-abortion literature to passers-by.
"Abortion is like apartheid," said one protester. "It discriminates against the unborn child."
At present only about 1,000 women a year qualify for legal abortions allowed under circumstances such as rape, incest and danger to the mother's life.
But official figures show that close to 50,000 women, overwhelmingly black, are hospitalised every year after botched backstreet abortions, from which 425 die.
Unofficial estimates say up to 120,000 women have illegal abortions in South Africa annually.
Women's rights groups and Mandela's ANC, which has a large majority in parliament, have thrown their weight behind relaxation of abortion laws.
